And I think what's sort of interesting to me about this, and we had talked about it when you were launching Ben March, or sort of soft launching, is there's a new monetization piece here that is not true of Reddit.
You want to sort of compensate the moderators for their time in some way.
I don't know if this is through equity or sort of the straight payment, but can you talk a little bit about that?
Yeah.
You know, when we first started big in 2004, before red launch.
Thousands and.
Thousands of people come in and contribute the content and they're not getting paid, they're just unpaid, you know, moderators, admins, or whatever you want to call them.
And then, you know, Red took that further and they opened up the taxonomy.
But it is a lot of work whenever we talk to some of the bigger Reddit moderators that are out there.

They talk about just, you know, the ones that have millions of members have to have round the clock, like call it a dozen plus people working on making sure to kick out bots to deal with all the spam issues.
They have the fights that are happening and they're not seeing any slice of that revenue and they don't control the audience either.
So you're talking about something where you're signing up and creating all this value for a platform, but you can't port that platform anywhere else.
You can't capture any email addresses, you can't stay in touch with that platform, you can be ousted at that platform.
In fact, when communities get to march, they're oftentimes trademarked and so you actually don't have the ability.
Wall Street Bets is a great one where the creator, one of the co creators of Wall Street Bets, tried to write a book called Wall Street Bets and was sued by Reddit.
When they're the actual ones that came up with the name.
And that just to.
When I talked to Alexis and we think about these things, that seems a little backwards.
Like if anything we should be more similar to Substack or Patreon or some of the others that are actually giving you much more control of your community and where that belongs to.
We're not the best platform for you, then by all means take your audience someplace else, import it, because that should be on us to provide the best platform.
That must be, I mean, pretty liberating to think about for these people.
I'm just wondering, do you see this, you know, community management as potentially like a full time job or just sort of a nice way of saying we appreciate what you've done.
And here's, you know.
Yeah.
In our conversations with some of the moderators, they would appreciate getting them.
We're doing nothing today.
One of them said, yeah, it'd be nice if I did this full time.
We had another one that said I would love a cup of coffee out of a month or something.
Something.
Right.
And so I think if your audience is big enough it should be, you know, properly compensated.
One of there's a bunch of models that we're exploring, one that I like.
Yeah, I think there's death by a thousand subscriptions.
I think the idea of like paying $5 for the community is just like a non starter.
It's like really difficult to do.
People have so many, you know, paid substacks or all the things that they're subscribing to.
We like the kind of Netflix model which is essentially where attention goes, money flows.
And so if we have a some type of platform where they can join and receive the attention based rewards for that.
So whether it be either ads based or subscription based, and you see transparently how that's flowing throughout the ecosystem.
So if you're part of slash Japanese woodworking, you can see, oh, they have this many subscribers.
It's going because they have so much attention here.
The dollars are flowing in, it's flowing to this moderator, this co creator and then they're going to throw parties, events, whatever it may be with the use of this proceed.
So we want to do that as transparently as possible and make it really simple.

So if you only spend a day there a month and you're paying $10 a month for subscription, you know, maybe it's a few cents that go your way, but in aggregate that's actually really meaningful if you get to millions of users.
Yeah, that's great.

And I asked because partly were talking backstage about the future of the workforce and how so many more people are going to be entrepreneurs, whether they realize it or not for now and looking for new ways to work.
You know, one thing I also wondered was, you know, you mentioned toxicity and it's obviously a huge problem.
I do.
And you're using AI tools to sort of combat that.

I do always wonder if that is a technical issue or a culture cultural issue because we're still seeing, you know, on X investors who we know have taken on these sort of very combative Personas to get attention.
I just think it's a very hard thing to overcome.
Yeah, I think everyone is on social for different reasons.
Some people say that they're tired of the toxicity, but they're the first to comment and jump in and dunk on someone.

That said, we think of these things as almost like smaller micro communities of really trusted people that you can eventually, with all these agents and everything that's coming online where they can befriend you and they can fake like an actual human.
We have to break this apart into verifiable, trustable, small micro communities around a theme, a topic.
And if we can create that intimacy and that idea of real connection with other humans, I think that's a huge win.
You don't need many people coming together to create like really highly valuable content and community around that.
So when we think about some of these things here, like dig for fun, dig to learn, dig for stay, those are kind of curated feeds that you can customize and say I want more of this or less of that.
And you have fine brain control over how you view and slice the data.

So one of the things that we did some data analysis on, which is before back in the old social days, if we had a politics section or category that would largely encapsulate, call it like 95% of all political commentary would be inside of that arena.
And so it was very easy because you could say, oh, turn this off, I just want to see anything more that's political.

But now politics is so pervasive and it's everywhere that we're having conversations and it like shows up around, you know, the name of a restaurant or whatever, like things are popping up all over the place.

And so what you have to do and what we do we can do now is essentially every single comment and story that comes in to gig, we can hit a ML pathway that we have to Google that will classify it in 15 different ways.
So is it hate speech, is it political, is it this or that?
We get back to scores and then we can say okay to the user.

If you don't want to see political chatter, you don't want to take place out or see the more controversial kind of like topics that are causing a lot of head hate and really anxiety provoking topics, you can kind of slide that slider any way that you want and then immediately that content filters out for you site wide.
And so we want to give users the control of that.

Whereas if you are into politics, you can jump into that arena and have fun and, or whatever it is that you do over there, but you can jump into that, but you'll know what you're about to walk into when you do.
So.

We're going to have the same issues with AI Sure.
